title: Courts Order Trump Admin to Fund SNAP Amid Shutdown
snippets: Two federal judges ordered the Trump administration to use emergency funding to provide SNAP benefits. But it's unclear how much, or when, those funds would be provided before the funding runs dry.
Judges in Massachusetts and Rhode Island ruled Friday afternoon that the Trump administration must fund SNAP during the government shutdown.
The administration said it wasn’t allowed to use a contingency fund of about $5 billion for the food-aid program.
Trump administration cannot suspend food aid benefits, US judges rule Reuters
Live updates: Trump administration must fund SNAP payments during the shutdown, judges rule AP News
Critics expressed alarm after government said it would totally suspend food aid programme utilised by 42 million people.
The Justice Department argued that the food stamp program, which feeds more than 40 million Americans, effectively did not exist anymore due to the shutdown.

One judge issued temporary restraining order while another judge ruled the government must continue to fund program that helps low-income households US politics live – latest updates Two federal judges issued back-to-back rulings on Friday in separate cases ordering the Trump administration to use c
titles: Federal judges order administration to pay SNAP benefits but what's next remains unclear
Trump signals he'll fund SNAP after federal judges ruled the administration must keep sending out benefits despite the shutdown
Judges order Trump administration to use emergency reserves for SNAP payments during the shutdown
Trump administration cannot suspend food aid benefits, US judges rule - Reuters
Live updates: Trump administration must fund SNAP payments during the shutdown, judges rule - AP News
US courts rule Trump cannot suspend food aid during government shutdown
Trump administration must pay SNAP benefits despite government shutdown, judge rules
Trump administration blocked from suspending Snap benefits for millions of Americans
summary: Two federal judges have ordered the Trump administration to continue funding the SNAP food aid program, which supports over 40 million low-income Americans, during the government shutdown. Despite the administration's claim of being unable to use a $5 billion contingency fund for SNAP, the rulings in Massachusetts and Rhode Island demand the maintenance of benefits. The exact amount and timing of these emergency funds remain uncertain as the shutdown continues.

title: Tanzania Protests: Hundreds Feared Dead as Election Violence Escalates
snippets: Tanzania opposition says hundreds killed in vote protests, UN calls for probe Reuters
The UN said it has "credible reports" that at least 10 protesters have been killed. The Chadema opposition party says hundreds have died in election-related violence, countrywide.

Demonstrators took to streets after president’s main challengers were excluded from ballot About 700 people have been killed during three days of election protests in Tanzania, the main opposition party has said. Protests erupted on election day on Wednesday over what demonstrators said was the stif
A diplomatic source tells the BBC there is credible evidence that at least 500 people have been killed.
Rights groups warned of growing violence against demonstrators after election in which the country’s president barred her two main opponents from running.
The United Nations said at least 10 people had been killed. Opposition leaders claimed the death toll could be in the hundreds, and one official called for the military to step in.
titles: Tanzania opposition says hundreds killed in vote protests, UN calls for probe - Reuters

summary: In Tanzania, election protests have erupted following the exclusion of the president's main challengers from the ballot, leading to widespread violence. The opposition party, Chadema, claims that around 700 people have been killed over three days of demonstrations. The United Nations, citing credible reports, acknowledges at least 10 deaths, while a diplomatic source suggests the toll could be at least 500. The UN has called for an investigation into the violence, which has escalated after the country's president barred her two main opponents from running, sparking international concern and ca

The series highlights include a complete game by Dodgers' Yoshinobu Yamamoto in Game 2. The action is covered on Sportsnet and includes detailed analysis on Jays Talk Plus.

title: Hurricane Melissa Kills 50, Devastates Caribbean Islands
snippets: Melissa dissipates, leaves destruction and at least 50 dead in Caribbean Reuters

This was

Hurricane Melissa's confirmed death toll climbed to 49 on Thursday, according to official reports, after wreaking destruction across much of the northern Caribbean and picking up speed as it headed past Bermuda in the North Atlantic.
Hurricane Melissa was "moving quickly away" from Bermuda early Friday after the death toll rose to nearly 50 people, officials said.

This move, despite Algeria's strong opposition, represents the strongest international endorsement yet for Morocco's retained rule over Western Sahara.

title: China Launches Shenzhou-21 with Crew and Mice to Tiangong Space Station
snippets: China sends its youngest astronaut to 'Heavenly Palace' space station Reuters
China has sent three new astronauts to its space station Tiangong as part of long-term space plans that include a moon landing.

summary: China successfully launched the Shenzhou-21 spaceship, carrying three astronauts and four mice to the Tiangong space station, as part of its long-term space exploration plans. This mission includes the country's youngest astronaut to date, furthering China's ambitions for a moon landing.

This decision was made public on Friday as Cameron seeks to address and change the regulations in women's boxing.

titles: Just Stop Oil trio cleared over Stonehenge orange powder protest

summary: Three Just Stop Oil protesters, Rajan Naidu, 74, Niamh Lynch, 23, and Luke, were acquitted of all charges related to their protest at Stonehenge, where they sprayed orange powder on the stones. They defended their actions by citing human rights law, arguing the protest aimed to highlight the climate emergency. The incident occurred the day before the 2024 solstice in Wiltshire, England.
